DIV1.P: PERFORMED At the Theatre-Royal, Drury-Lane. BY RICHARD GUMBERLAND, ESQ.
DUBLIN: Printed by H. Fitzpatrick, FOR MESSRS. P. BYRNE, P. WOGAN, W. JONES G. BURNET, J. RICE, J. JONES, AND G. FOLINGSBY.

LG.L: IN every rank of life the friends of love,
(From Goddesses below to Gods above)
We claim you for our patrons, and prefer
Our suit to those, whose judgment cannot err;
For you have hearts, and we make no appeal
But to the test of what those hearts shall feel.
If Nature quits us, every hope is fled,
For we have nought to tender in her stead,
No pageant to exhaust the Treasurer's chest,
Or rob the Painter of his natural rest:
Failing to please, we aim not to surprise;
Palling your ears, we cannot feast your eyes.
But we believe you never will submit
To naturalize these substitutes for wit,
Therefore it is, our author keeps the stage
With all the pertinacity of age;
Not in defiance of the Public will,
But in the hope that you'll support him still;
Not in exclusion of another's name,
For dear to him is every brother's fame,
But to shew genius of a stronger growth,
Which else might sink to indolence and sloth,
That feeble plants, when nourish'd by your care,
Ev'n in the winter of their age will bear.
If, ere the hour shall come that lay to rest
All hopes and fears within the human breast,
Once more your Poet ventures to convene
His Muse's Patrons to the moral scene,
'Tis in the hope that for your favors past
He may yet make some small return at last.
Here, if he fails, and shou'd this night's event
Prove that your favors and his fires are spent,
What on the part of candor shall be said,
But that his heart was stouter than his head?
But that, advancing to a fresh attack,
He dropt, and "died with harness on his back!"

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: WELL! I could almost swear—yet I won't be sure. I wish he would look back once again.—Yes it is, by St. George, it is my dear brother Frederick.—Ah! my sweet fellow, wel∣come to England! Don't you remember little David?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: David! may I believe my eyes? 'Tis he, sure enough. Come to my arms my brave lad! Why you are alter'd out of knowledge, and in the navy uniform—That's right, my boy, there you're in your proper line.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Aye, aye, Sir!—But we'll talk of that by-and-by. How are you in the first place? How fares it with you, my hearty? where are you come from? what sort of a cruize have you had in t'other country? Have you fallen in with father?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: No, nor do I wish him to know of my arrival as yet.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Be it so, be it so! Mum's the word for that.—Are you come home full or empty? Egad, you'll find father cling plaguily by the claws, damn'd close in the lockers.—If you are bare of the ready, I've plenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Thank you, David, thank you heartily; but I can shift. Keep your money my good lad.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Not that, with your leave; I know a little better than so, we may hope.—But what brings you home o'the sudden?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: My father's peremptory commands.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Enough said: then 'tis on account of sister's wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I believe not—but I did not know till this moment she was married. Tell me the particu∣lars, for 'tis interesting intelligence.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Why she's married, that's all I can tell you; she has got a mate of father's own chusing; so he thinks he has done a mighty feat, and rigg'd her out for a fair weather voyage; but between you and me, I suspect there's foul wind in feather∣bed bay, and a kind of cat-and-dog harmony on board between 'em; that's my notion.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I can well believe it: She has not the best temper in the world. What is the gentle∣man's name and condition?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Wrangle is his name, and wrangling I suspect to be his condition; but I heartily dislike the man, and therefore I wou'd not have you take his character from me: see him, and judge for yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: There is one marriage in our family then to begin with; and now I must tell you, David, in confidence, that I do not believe it was on account of this wedding my father call'd me home in such haste, but with a view to another.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Like enough, like enough; that's your look-out, thank Heaven, and not mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P:
Bad luck for me, David, if it is as I fear; but you know Sir Paul Ruby is now dead, and my first love is a widow, young, blooming, and
mistress of a mine of wealth: You can remember Clara Middleton, how devotedly I was attach'd to her, and how cruelly my father tore me from her.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Do I remember it? Yes, to be sure, and in my mind never forgave old crusty for his hard∣heartedness to this hour; but if that be his sport, let him come on: By the Lord Harry, Fred. you'll be a gay fellow if you can bring that prize into harbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Hush! hush! that can never be.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Why you are in the right not to be too sure, for all the world is after her; but if she has a hankering for you still, you know—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Heaven forbid!

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Well, well, I won't flatter you, brother, you are a little gone off to be sure, rather the worse for wear, a small matter out of trim, but we can soon put that to rights, if your timbers are but staunch.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: It is not there I shou'd fail, let us hope; but if death was the alternative, I cou'd not give my hand to Lady Ruby.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: I take you now; you'll be no man's se∣cond; I see how it is with you, first oar or none at all.—Lord love you, what a whim is that! 'Tis no denial to a good ship because another man has commanded her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: You are wide of the mark, friend David; it is not that I object to Lady Ruby as a widow, for I dare say she is still beautiful as an angel.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: That's more than I know, for I never saw one; but I'm sure she's as fresh and as fine as a daisey.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Why that is as lowly a similitude as you can well find for her; but with all her charms, and all her riches, and all the love she cou'd bestow upon me, were it warm and flattering as in our fondest moments, the barrier between us would be insuperable: fate has disunited us for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Then fate has play'd you a very foul trick, let me tell you; for, search the world through, you will no where find her fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: If I dare trust you with a secret, I wou'd put that to the trial; and yet I think you are too good a fellow to tell tales.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Give me none to tell, and that's a sure way to prevent it; but I think you might venture to trust me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: This it is, and I'll make a short story of it.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Do so!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I have brought a virtuous and lovely girl with me into England—

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Who has been the preserver of my life, the companion of my journey from Padua to this place, and whom I have pledg'd myself to make the partner of my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Your wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: My wife: the word is passed, and I must keep it.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: To be sure you must; but I'm sorry for it; there's no more to be said.—Death and fury! What a torrent will you have about your ears! Why, father will come down on you like a water∣spout.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I am now seeking out some place where she can be lodg'd and boarded with people of re∣putation, till I can arrange my affairs; but I have been so long out of England, that I am almost as much a stranger in London as herself. Perhaps, David, you can help me out.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Why that's what I'm thinking of: I have a friend, a right one, as staunch an old cock as ever crow'd, my navy agent, Billy Bustler by name. I'm to dine with him to-day—and he has a sister Kate by the same token; a good soul! but if your Miss is'nt of the right sort, look you—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Oh fie, fie,! Can you suppose any other∣wise?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P:
Well, well! but a word in time, you know—for Kate's a pure maiden, you must think, with a good deal of the buckram about her. Lord!
how I do set her up sometimes. So, if you've stowed away all your courtship, d'ye see, and got your marriage tack fairly a-board, why upon these terms I think I have interest enough with Kate to coax her into compliance.—Now, what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Let us about it directly; for my lovely charge is expecting me, and time is precious.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Say no more, my bright fellow! As for Billy, he's a sure card. Give me your arm, and we'll be down upon him in a whiff.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. A Chamber in Mr. Wrangle's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Ah, my dear, dear Mr. Wrangle, I have been sighing for a sight of you this many a long hour: Where in the world have you hidden your∣self from the eyes of your fond doating wife?—Come, come, my love, look kindly upon me: We that are so happy in each other, should always meet with rapture.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Well, my dear Lyddy, and who is so rapturous as I? Where is the husband that so doats upon his wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Don't say so, don't say so. Can you lay your hand upon your heart, and say you love me to the full as well as ever you did?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Better, better.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: No, you don't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Yes, I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: I'll swear you don't; I know to a certainty your affection abates, whereas mine in∣creases every hour: nay, it is so excessive, that I am almost afraid it grows troublesome to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Don't fear it; from my soul I believe our fondness for each other is equal and alike: The uninterrupted harmony of our nuptial state, and the fidelity I have ever manifested—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P:
Well, and what has my fidelity been, I would ask? Notorious, unique, the talk of all
the town. I am really so pointed at in all compa∣nies as a mere domestic creature, that I am almost asham'd to shew my face in any fashionable circle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Never mind their sneering; your own conscience can acquit you of deserving it.—If I were you, Mrs. Wrangle, I wou'd sometimes pass an evening at home, if it were only to shew them you despise their spleen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Sometimes, Mr. Wrangle! sometimes pass an evening at home! Where is the woman of fashion passes so many evenings at home as I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: The present won't be one of the num∣ber, if I may judge from your dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: The present indeed! How can you ex∣pect it? Is'nt it opera night? Wou'd you wish to deprive me of my only pleasure? Is there any thing in life I love so well as an opera?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Oh yes! your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Well, my husband to be sure—my husband is before every pleasure, so you need not take me up so quickly: for you know, my dear, you are all in all to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: With the opera to help it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: The opera indeed! You should be asham'd to mention the opera, where I think, con∣sidering all things, I might expect to be indulg'd with a box to myself, instead of scrubbing into the pit, as I do at present; which give me leave to say, few women of my pretensions would put up with.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Keep your temper Mrs. Wrangle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: And don't I keep my temper, Mr. Wrangle? Is'nt it the part of a friend to let you know the whole town cries out upon you? that you're the public talk? your character suffers by it—People know what a fortune I brought you; and you know in your heart, my dear, that if you had a little more of the gentleman in your spirit—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: 'Sblood Madam, if I had a great deal less, you are enough to call it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: There, there! now you are going to be in one of your antarums.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Then why do you provoke me to it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: I provoke you! I only tell you of your faults, and you have not temper to hear of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: You are very sharp-sighted in spying out my faults, methinks, and at the same time either shut your eyes upon your own, or find them too incurable to meddle with.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: I plead to no fault but the fault of keep∣ing terms with you; and that I'm resolved to cor∣rect out of hand: I'll put up with your ill humours no longer; my father, my family, the whole town shall know your treatment of me. I cou'd bear my lot well enough, if the world did but know I was not that happy wife they suppose me to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Lady Ruby.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Best impart your sorrows to her then; she, you know, is your bosom friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: My dear Lady Ruby.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: My dear Mrs Wrangle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Here's a tender greeting! An honest man would suppose these women had a regard for each other; nothing less at heart with either.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Oh! you incorrigible creature! téte-à-téte with your own wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: I have the grace at least of taking a hint, when the friends of my wife wou'd dispense with my company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Did you ever see the like? Upon my life, Lydia, you have spoilt that good man of your's, and made him as freakish as a humour'd child: There is not one in a thousand of that silly sex can bear being petted.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Never think about him; he grows quite intolerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Bless me! I could not have believed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: No, because you will believe me what I am not, never have been, nor ever shall be—happy with that man: My temper is quick, his sullen; my nature is open and sincere; his dark and jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: He jealous! Mr. Wrangle jealous!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Oh! extremely so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I cou'd not have believ'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Now cannot I for the life of me com∣prehend why you cou'd not have believ'd it: be∣cause, tho' I am sufficiently guarded in my con∣duct, especially before him, yet I shou'd hope I am not too vain when I suppose some few attractions, some small pretensions, may still be said to belong to me—tho' comparatively nothing with what your ladyship possesses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Certainly, my dear Madam, you have charms in full measure; and if you rather chuse to be complimented upon them than your discre∣tion, your husband shall be credited by me for all the jealousy you think fit to ascribe to him, with as much or as little cause as you may be disposed to allow of

P.Q: I believe there is no woman but wou'd be mortified if her husband was to say to her, “It is not in your power to make me jealous.”

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I grant you, the power is desirable, the exercise of it an experiment of some danger: 'tis like a dormant title; one wou'd not give it up, tho it may not suit us to assume it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: A-propos, to a title—now your year of widowhood is up, have you ask'd a certain question of that little heart of your's, and has the sly thing ever been brought to confession about this same Lord Sensitive, who follows you up and down like your shadow?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Oh yes—I've talk'd with the sly thing, as you call it, by the hour about him, and a very edifying conversation it was, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Aye, indeed! as how!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Why, I took it roundly to task, for I began to perceive it had got some foolish flutter∣ings, which you good wives know nothing of—now this I did not like; for, being as you see a free woman, I resolve to profit by past sorrows, and not enslave myself any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Humph! that's a widow's resolution, made without meaning, and broken without re∣morse; but for my part, as I don't believe you are at all in love with him, I must wonder what amusement you can find in tormenting him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Law, child! the man torments him∣self; he takes all trouble off my hands, and makes me a bye-stander in my own quarrels: He sees things that never had existence; hears things that were never said; and seems to have a phantom ever at his beck, like a conjuror's familiar, that whis∣per's in his ear, and drives him upon extravagan∣cies that exceed all credibility.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Lord Sensitive begs permission to pay his respects to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Look you there now—phantom again.—Better send him away, for if he gets a haunt of your house, he'll be under your couch, behind your bed∣curtains, not a corner, closet, nor cupboard will be free from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Now I won't send him away, for I perceive she's jealous—Provoking creature! how vexatiously well drest she is!
—Shew my Lord Sensitive up.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I have presum'd upon the privilege of an old acquaintance—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: To come in search of a new one.—I am much beholden to Lady Ruby for the honor of this visit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Now that is quite cruel, Mrs. Wrangle; it really gives me pain; but it is my misfortune to have every attention of mine misunderstood.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Wou'd your lordship be understood then to have no attention for any lady in this room besides myself?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I wou'd be thought not to want more temptations than one for visiting Mrs. Wrangle; but whatever interpretation you may please to put upon my attentions, I must think myself highly honor'd when they are regarded as an object either by yourself or Lady Ruby.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: My Lord!—meaning me?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I thought I heard my own name; that was all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: And do do I offend by pronouncing it? If so, I fear I am guilty even in my sleep—nay in my prayers; for I am apt to name you then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Now that's too much, by all that's tender!—Heavens, what a Philander! Such milk and sugar speeches make me sick.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I am very unlucky, ladies, and perhaps unseasonably intrude upon some more interesting business; Lady Ruby's thoughts at least seem to be otherwise engag'd than upon the present subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: You are not quite out of your guess; they were just then upon a ramble.—I think, my lord, you was last summer in Italy—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: In Italy! Yes, yes, madam, I was in Italy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Did you visit Padua?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Padua! No—What do I say? Yes, I have at been Padua.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Did you make any long stay there?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Really I—I have almost forgot how long I staid.—But pray, madam, why do you wish to know? Have you any particular motive for en∣quiring how long I staid at Padua, or what pass'd whilst I was there?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: None, none at all; not the least curio∣sity, be assur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Don't believe, her, my lord; she has a motive for every thing, and never speaks without forethought.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: How can you say so? Oh! you spite∣ful thing, what a persecution have you drawn upon me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Indeed and indeed, Lady Ruby, you have alarm'd me: I feel every thing that falls from you, and am tremblingly alive to the slightest whis∣per that may wound my reputation where I am most interested to guard it. I entreat, if you have heard any thing against me, that you will suffer me to defend myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: No time like the present, therefore I'll charitably leave you together—which is a good-natur'd way of making you perfectly dis∣agreeable to each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: It is now in your power, Lady Ruby, to make this abrupt departure of Mrs. Wrangle's the kindest action of her life, and the happiest mo∣ment of mine—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: My lord, I don't perfectly understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: By permitting me to justify my charac∣ter to your entire satisfaction:—I will suppose, madam, you have heard that I had an idle attach∣ment at Padua.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I did not hear it was idle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Admit it was a serious one then, for ar∣gument's sake—such fooleries, I should hope, do not stick fast to a man's character, especially after the object is shaken off and forgotten.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Perhaps that may be the worst part of the story, if the lady was not unworthy—but I am no inquisitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I'll not impeach the lady's reputation, neither will I allow it to be said I have dealt disho∣norably with her in any shape—If any gentleman dares to fix that aspersion upon me, I am ready with my answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I don't doubt it; there's a certain ar∣gument that answers every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I guess from whom your information is deriv'd: Mr. Frederick Mowbray has been at Pa∣dua—is there still perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Hold, my Lord, I must set you right in one particular; and I insist on your believing me, when I declare to you, upon my honor, that Fre∣derick Mowbray is not my informer, neither does my information come by any other channel from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: May I ask the lady's name you suppose me to have been attach'd to?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Sabina Rosny—of noble parents, who had perish'd under the axe in France; an orphan fugitive, young, beautiful, and friendless.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I befriended her, I protected her.—If our best deeds are to be perverted by detraction, and then urg'd against us as crimes, who is safe?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Well, madam, I hope that is my case.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I hope it is—and if it is, you'll treat such stories with contempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: And so I do; but I am penetrated, cut to the heart, confounded with—with contrition—no, not that—but with shame and vexation, that such stories should be entertained by you in any serious light.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Your agitation makes them serious.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: My agitation is proportion'd to the—to the agony it gives me to say—that I regard my∣self as dismiss'd, discarded, banish'd from your sight for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Guilty upon my honor!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Well, my dear Lady, you have quar∣rel'd as I suppos'd, and parted with high words: and now if his lordship should fall to his prayers, I shou'd doubt if it will be a blessing he'll bestow upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I step back once more, and for the last time—Confusion! Mrs. Wrangle here?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Shall I stop him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: No, I beseech you let him go.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: He is terribly agitated.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Not a whit more than will do him good; let us hope his fermentation will refine him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Ah, my dear lady, I see plainly how it will be; you will marry that man; positively you will marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: If you are positively right and infallible in your predictions, it must be so; if I have any thing to say to it, I shall beg leave to doubt—But time flies fast in your society, and I have been making you a most unconscionable visit—May I request your servant to order up my coach?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Must I part from you?—Who waits? (Servant appears.) Order Lady Ruby's fervants.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Well, good bye to you!—we shall meet at the opera.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: My dear, dear friend, all happiness at∣tend you!

SP.SPEAKER: Billy Bustler.
SP.P: WELL, Kate! well, girl; now let us hear how it goes in the kitchen quarter—It comes a little mal-à propos to be sure, for I'm plaguy busy; but I know you like to set out a dinner, so give us your bill o' fare.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Why, you know, Billy, this is Michael∣mas-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I know that fast enough: I hope you have a goose.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Law! brother! how you snap one up—to be sure there is a goose.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: At first course I hope—bottom dish.—

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: No, the goose is at top.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: I tell you no, my goose shall be at bot∣tom.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Why then you must have two gooses, for no one shall cut it up but myself. There's a boil'd leg of corn'd pork for your carving; I hope you call that a bottom dish—with a pease-pudding on one side, and a bowl of apple-sauce on the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, Kate, I can't give up the goose; I love to have him under my own nose, smoking with sage and onions—Oh! he's a savoury fellow—can't give him up, Kate; can't, upon my soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P:
Then you must give up me, for I won't sit at table on any other terms.—You indeed to dis∣pute with me about tops and bottoms!—with me, who cou'd have set out seven and eleven before you was man enough to tuck a napkin under your chin! Do pr'ythee keep to your own receipt-book, and leave me to mine; I know it all, from a lark to a loin of beef, and in the oeconomy of the
table woud'nt hold a candle to Hannah Glass her∣self, if she was living and here present.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Heyday! how came this to pass? here's a breeze indeed! here's a ripple!—Kitty, my charmer, who has vext you?

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Why, Billy has vext me; he will chatter about things he knows nothing of.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: I've done, I've done; serve up the goose in your own way.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Out upon him, for a lubber! he has been running foul of the kitchen hawlyards, after his old fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: No, no, it's all over; there's an end; I knock under: Your presence, Pickle, always makes peace.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Why, how long have you liv'd by the sea, friend Bustler, not to find out that it's sure to make rough water where two tides meet? Kitty's temper is as smooth as a mill-pond, if you won't put in your oar. Come, come, let us be all in good humour with each other, for I've a favor to ask of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: What is that, lapwing?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Oh! quite a small matter; I know you'll grant it at the first word.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: It shall go hard but I'll try for it. Let us hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Why, 'tis only to accomodate a friend of mine with a night or two's lodging in your spare cabin.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Is that all?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Yes; that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Any friend of your's, my dear boy, shall be welcome to my house, bed and board, for as long as he likes.—Why did'n't you bring the gentleman with you?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Gentleman! No, no, the gentleman in this case happens to be a lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Ah! gemini! you little wicked devil, would you foist your naughty hussies into my house?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Who says she's a naughty hussey? She's as spotless a virgin as yourself, only she is not so obstinately bent to continue one; for she's about to be married out of hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Get you gone, get you gone! I'll have nothing to do with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Hold, hold, let us understand this a lit∣tle better. What is the lady's name—who is she going to marry—and how are you interested about her? I don't think David Mowbray would bring a bad woman into my family.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Why, who can suppose I wou'd? But with respect to entering into her history with you, I can't do it; for 'tis brother Frederick's affair, and he'll satisfy you in all points. It is not I that am going to marry her, but he; all I know is, that she is a person of rank, and an emigrant. Take notice, I have never seen her, and moreover it is a close secret from father.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Billy, Billy, if it is a secret affair, don't meddle or make with it: as sure as can be you'll get into hot water with Sir Miles Mowbray.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B
SP.P: Hot water indeed! let him take care then he don't scald his own fingers. I shall act the strait part by my friend David; if he deceives me, that is his fault; if I deceive him, I am a flincher, and no true Englishman—so I say the lady shall be welcome: I say it, and who shall gainsay it?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Come, sweet Kate, it only wants your concurrence; take a little pity into your heart for a poor orphan stranger, driven out of her own country by the murderers of her parents, and give her a small sample of your hospitality, for the honor of old England.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P:
Nay if she is an orphan and a stranger, and a fugitive from that cruel country, who but a monster wou'd refuse to take her in? I'll not be outdone in charity by any body.—Let her come
when she will, I'll do every thing in my power for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Well said, Kate! thou art a kind soul, tho' a dear lover of a little contradiction.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: When there's a good heart at bottom, what matters it how you get to it?—But I'm going to my brother, and when I bring him in my hand, I shall bring one, for whose honor I will vouch with my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: So, child, how comes it to pass you are not at the opera to-night?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: The fates decreed it otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Nonsense! the fates indeed! You have other reasons than they can give you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Well, if you are not contented with the fates, you must make enquiry amongst the casualties—Your coach broke down with me at the opera door.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: My coach! my new coach!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: The very same; and for an accident methinks you have come of reasonably well. If my limbs had been broken at the same time, you wou'd have had double repairs on your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Humph! are my horses safe?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: They are jobs, you know; you need have no feeling for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: How did you come home?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Took the first carriage that was offer'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: And whose was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Colonel, Colonel—I can't think of the man's name.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Come, come, I know your man. I'll bet ten to one 'twas Colonel Doricourt's.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: That's high odds, but you'd win the wager.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: You came home with Colonel Do∣ricourt—?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Exactly so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Damnation! then there are more re∣pairs on my hands than a broken carriage; there is a ruin'd reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Carry in your damages: the gentle∣man will satisfy you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: And do you think I'll be satisfied with this cool contempt, this insolent indifference to my just remonstrances? No, Madam, your new method of insensibility won't serve: I'll make you feel, before we part.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Keep your temper, Mr. Wrangle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: I'll not keep my temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Throw it aside then, and get a better; for it is thoroughly worn out, and no longer fit for any gentleman's wear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: So, so, so! very good, very good! Here you both are, close as ever: here I left you, and here I find you, still the same, ever fond and loving, ever happy in each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Oh! supremely happy!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Both superlatively blest!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I know it well: and why are you so superlatively blest, but because you had the grace to discover that I cou'd choose better for you than you cou'd for yourself? Why is a father call'd the head of his family, but as it is his business to think for all those whose heads can't think for themselves? The human heart, children, has been my peculiar study; and as I have kept myself ex∣empt from all those passions that disturb it, I may say without vanity, I am master of the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: And pray, Sir, may I ask how you be∣came thus learned in the passions, having never experienc'd the effects of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: As a physician finds out a disease without feeling it; by natural intuition and deep reflection.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: And by which of these do you disco∣ver to a certainty that I am as happy as I pretend to be?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Can I fail to discover it is day when the sun shines? If there were any hypocrisy in your heart, can you suppose it would escape me? When your brother Frederic was in love, did not I find it out? Yet I never was the dupe of that nonsensical passion myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: So I shou'd think, Sir, when you un∣dertook to reason him out of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Aye, Madam, and now you shall see I'll reason him into it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: That I shou'd guess will be no hard task, if Lady Ruby is the object. Mr. Mowbray will be a happy man if he obtains her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs W.
SP.P: He'll be a rich one at least: why you shou'd so decidedly say he will be a happy one, I am at a loss to guess, because I know the lady is no favourite of your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: I can have no favourites, whilst one reigns mistress of my heart, compar'd with whom all other objects are as nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Do you hear that, Lyddy? By my soul, Wrangle, tho' I say it to my daughter's face, (and she's a good girl, I confess) thou art enough to spoil any wife in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Not with kindness, I shou'd think.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Can I possibly be too kind to such a wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: No, but you may talk too much about it; you may turn her head with too many fine speeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: I wish you had heard what fine speeches he made to me just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I don't doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: I had the misfortune to have my coach broke down at the opera. I have seen husbands that will fret and fume at such an accident, and scold the poor wife without mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Aye, those are peevish paltry fellows truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Are they not? Yet even these, who are such tyrants out of fight, shall be sycophants to your face, and pass themselves upon the world for the best of husbands, by the mean resource of flattery and fine speeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Very true, they are the most loathsome characters in nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: I think so from my soul—and all the while the poor wife, tho' in fact the most miserable of beings, shall be falsly suppos'd the happiest of women.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: That is the most provoking circum∣stance of all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Insupportably so in my opinion—Then the odious creature is so jealous upon every trifling occasion, and so petulant withal, that one knows not which he is most to be despis'd for, his capti∣ousness or his cruelty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Ah child, child! had you been re∣fractory and self-will'd, all these miseries might have fallen upon you; whereas, by following my judgment in the great concern of life, you have all the blessings of wedlock, and escape its sorrows.—So farewell! I leave you happy; I have made you happy; and if I have the same success with Lady Ruby, to whom I am now going, we shall all be happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: My dearest life, permit me to attend upon you—Honor me so far as to give me your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Oh! that I could recall the day when I did give you my hand! neither force, nor flattery, nor all the fortune upon earth, shou'd prevail with me to consent to it.
SP.STAGE: A Chamber in Lady Ruby's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: When Lord Sensitive's confidential ser∣vant inform'd you of his attachment for Sabina Rosny, did he speak of her as a woman of character?

SP.SPEAKER: W. Woman.
SP.P: Oh yes, my lady; he gave the young gentlewoman a very high character.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: For her discretion, I ask you?

SP.SPEAKER: W. Woman.
SP.P: For her good qualities, my lady, her accomplishments, and above all, for her beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Pooh! her beauty is out of the ques∣tion; I am simply talking of her character, of her conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: W. Woman.
SP.P: Pardon me, madam, I did not think it handsome to be over-curious about conduct; for I concluded Mr. Carrington too much a man of honor to betray his master's secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: So it shou'd seem indeed, by his taking you into counsel for the keeping them.—You may leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Lord Sensitive deliver'd this himself, and bids me say he attends to know your ladyship's pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Very well!
—My compli∣ments to his lordship, and if he wishes to walk up, I am at home.
So! here's another explanation to undergo—Ah! man, man! positively thou art the most irra∣tional, nonsensical animal in the creation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Am I permitted once more to ap∣proach you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: You have the same permission, my Lord, that you always had.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P:
I am sensible my visits can no longer be acceptable to you: where suspicion has taken hold, kindness cannot keep its place; I had there∣fore determined never to intrude again, but a natu∣ral wish to attempt my justification, and, more than all, a natural weakness, which my heart cannot in∣instantly
shake off, induce me once more, and for the last time, to solicit an admission.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I am happy, to see your lordship upon any terms; and I hope you will repeat you visits for the last time so often, that our ac∣quaintance will improve by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Ah, madam, madam, whilst you can sport with my feelings in this manner, your levity convinces me how indifferent I am to you: nay, I believe from my soul I am become your aversion; and I am astonish'd, when your ladyship so well knows the real motives of my visits here, you have not ordered your doors to be shut against so un∣welcome an intruder.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Pray, my Lord, what is our quarrel just now? and why shou'd my doors, that are apt to be open to all persons of honor, and my friends in general, be shut against you in particular?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Because I understand some tattling busy∣body has impressed you with unfavourable notions of my conduct, in an affair, which delicacy for∣bids me to explain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Then let delicacy prevail with you to forbear the subject. We may be good friends without searching into the secrets of each other's heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Right, madam, 'tis a compromise that saves us both from an unpleasant task: my heart is not pure enough for your inspection; your's, was I to search it, would disclose all the tender feel∣ings, all the fond unabated affections, that are there glowing and alive for a certain person, who sways it still, tho' absent and neglectful.—'Sdeath, madam! it is a discovery that would drive me into madness, nor will I stoop to friendship where I have once aspir'd to love!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: That is sincere at least: you think my nature steady to a first attachment; credit yourself for the same principle, and we have each of us our separate pursuits; they clash no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: May I then be permitted to ask you one plain question?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: With all my heart; propose it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Are you not at this moment still so wedded to a first attachment, as to be no longer susceptible of any other?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: That is a question, let me observe to you, that none but the most intimate friend could expect an answer to; how then can your lordship look for it, when you will not submit to be re∣garded in that character?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: But if a lover presum'd to put such a question, wou'd you wave it in his case?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: If he was a man I dislik'd, I might perhaps avail myself of so fair an opportunity for getting rid of him; if he was one I esteem'd, I shou'd be sorry to find he had so self-tormenting a curiosity belonging to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Oh, loveliest of women! ever charming, ever irresistible, pardon my too-anxious sensibility, and pity one who lives but in your sight. I find it is impossible to escape—scorn me, trifle with me, torture me as you will, still I must adore you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Must you be always in extremes? Now you are more intolerable than ever.—Let go my hand I desire of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Grudge me not this short respite from my anguish; for pity's sake do not leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Positively I must.—Ah! you have crush'd my hand—release it, I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Spare me these few moments, I am not so presumptuous as to flatter myself they can last.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I hardly think they shou'd; I don't believe any human hand could bear to be so squeez'd much longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Thus let me atone the injury I have done it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I perceive, my lord, our interviews should last no longer than whilst we keep up the spirit of controversy; as soon as ever we begin to be of the same mind, it is time we should part.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Sir Miles Mowbray begs the honor of a few-minutes conversation with your ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord. S.
SP.P: There, there, there! all my apprehen∣sion are verified.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Hush, hush!—wait without a few mo∣ments.—(Servant retires.)—I confess I'm puzzled to account for this visit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: So am not I—His motives are too clear: your fortune is the loadstone; he comes to make proposals for his son.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Ridiculous! Go, go, you shall not stay a minute longer; I must admit him.—Who waits?—Tell Sir Miles Mowbray, I am at his ser∣vice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Well, Madam—if it must be so, and if Sir Miles's business is so very interesting—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Don't be so tiresome.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I will obey—And yet—Oh! Lady Ruby think of me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I am your ladyship's very humble servant—greatly oblig'd to you for this indulgence, very greatly oblig'd to you indeed. I am a suitor to your ladyship, under favor, for a few moments of your patience, if my request be not unsea∣sonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I am entirely at your command, Sir Miles.—Be pleas'd to take a chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Not so my lady; let me entreat you to be seated first.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Pray use no ceremony—With your leave I will sit by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I humbly thank you.—In truth, my lady, I do greatly covet to be near you, near in every sense. Believe me I shou'd greet the moment as the happiest of my life, that connected me and mine in the closest and nearest alliance with your ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Has that always been your wish?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Madam!—My lady!—(Ahem) I am not fure I rightly comprehend your ladyship's question.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: If I remind you of your past opinion, Sir Miles, it is because I wou'd not have you be deceived as to your present one—I do not think that within the period since you and I have ceas'd to be acquainted I have any such acquirements to boast of as shou'd induce you think better of me now that I am a widow, than you did before I was a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: 'Tis a proof of your modesty, that you are pleas'd to say so; and what is so engaging? 'tis a token of your candor and sincerity (amiable qualities!) and I always did you the justice to say that you possess'd them in a very eminent degree.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Indeed! did you say that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I did, I did upon my soul—I said it, I thought it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Then I suspect you do not think better of a woman for being only modest, candid, and sincere,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Pardon me, Madam! Can I give a stronger proof how highly I esteem those virtues than by tendering you my son, my eldest son Frederick?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Bless me! wou'd you recommend so bad a bargain to your son?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: How so, my lady? how so? Why do you say—so bad a bargain?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Because you have only reckon'd up a ragged troop of virtues, which you once turn'd from your doors, when they were in better plight than at present, without naming money, which, I believe, in your opinion, is a virtue worth them all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P:
I know the value of money, Madam, tho' I won't call it a virtue; and I own to you that Sir Paul Ruby's property, so worthily bequeath'd to your ladyship, consolidated with what Frederick,
as my heir, may expect, are circumstances not to be overlooked in the calculations of a prudent father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Well, Sir Miles, I am still so much your son's friend as to rejoice at having discover'd, that when interest prompts you to seek out an alliance for him, the good qualities of the lady you contract with will be no bar to your bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Very much on the contrary, very much indeed; and therefore let me hope, my good lady, when my son, whom I look for hourly, shall arrive, you will graciously permit me to lay him at your feet.—In this hope I humbly take my leave—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Your patience for a moment:—What∣ever hopes you are pleased to found upon this con∣versation, I must candidly tell you they are not at all to be depended upon; and recollect, Sir Miles, that if my affection for your son is now ex∣tinguish'd, it was your own authority that put an end to it;—let me add, that if I am not greatly flatter'd by the honor of this visit, it is because I clearly comprehend the motives of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: My lady, I—I—I am your very humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Your most obedient, Sir Miles Mow∣bray.—Who waits?

O, Frederick, Frederick! false forgetful man! Did you but feel those wishes, which your inte∣rested father expresses, how little wou'd you need an advocate!—how easily wou'd my resentment be appeas'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Frederick.
SP.P: FRIEND of my life! my benevolent preserver! I have now happily accomplish'd one effort of my gratitude, by escorting you to an asylum, where persecution cannot reach you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Generous Mowbray! I do wish to tell you, in the language you have taught me, how my poor heart is penetrated with your goodness to me, but I am not eloquent; I can only say I do thank you for your care of me, and for bringing me to your charitable country, which I do honor from my soul; indeed I do honor it; but, alas! it is not for me ever to be happy in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Why do you say that? I am incapable of deceiving you: this instant I am going to my fa∣ther, and be assur'd it shall not be many days before the dubious situation you are in shall be honorably done away, and all my promises fulfill'd

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: No, no, no, my good friend, I shall not call upon you for those promises; we are now in England, and those promises are nothing, they are void.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: What can you mean, Sabina? Do you suspect my integrity?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P:
I do not suspect you at all—but you was sick, take notice, very sick, and derang'd in your senses, when, because I did do my possible in pity and compassion, to assist you in your malady, you was pleas'd to make those promises you speak, and I did let them pass for the time, saying nothing to the contrary of them, because they were very good and commodious for me, as a single woman, travelling alone with you, under pro∣tection of your honor; but now that you are at home▪ again, and, thanks to Heaven! in good
health, I shall not be so base to let you ruin your∣self by marrying poor me, only because you pledg'd your word when you did hardly know what that word meant.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Nobly conceiv'd! but I am not that wretch, to sacrifice my honor to a mean and mer∣cenary evasion: Tho' my heart has been wounded, as you know, it has not been debas'd; and I am determin'd to go this instant to my father, and an∣nounce the resolution I have taken.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Stop, I conjure you, stop! I have some∣thing on my mind to tell you.—Ah, misericorde! What is a-coming now?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Bless me! I did not know this room was occupied: I beg a thousand pardons—Mr. Mowbray!—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Lady Ruby!—this is indeed a surprize.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I desire I may not break in upon your conference, Sir. My business with the master of this house may be transacted in his office.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Our conference, Madam, is at an end. I was on the point of my departure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: By no means let me hasten it: I shou'd be sorry to deprive the lady of one moment of your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: It has been my good fortune to be the lady's companion for some time, and we are just arriv'd in England. Mademoiselle Rosny is an emigrant of noble birth, as much to be admir'd for her virtues, as she is to be pitied for her mis∣fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Rosny! is that the lady's name?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, that is my name: Alas! I am the last that bear it: Those that did honor to it once are now no more: I am a miserable solitary relict.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: So young an orphan! How my heart bleeds for you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: How good, to feel for the distress'd and stranger! Ah, had you known my parents:—They perish'd at Marseilles; I fled to Padua, but sor∣row overtook me; I had great sufferings there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I can well believe it.—Lord Sensitive has that to answer for.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Sabina, you shall spare yourself the pain∣ful recital: Lady Ruby, if I rightly know her, is not curious to inquire into the private histories of the unfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: In point of idle curiosity, I hope you do me no more than justice; but to know misfor∣tunes for the purpose of relieving them, permit me to say that I am curious.—If Mademoiselle Rosny shou'd prefer the protection of one of her own sex to her present situation, my heart and house are open to receive her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Oh! that is great consideration for me truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: What say you, amiable Sabina? I am, like you, a solitary woman: will you consent to be my companion and friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: I have all possible empressment for your goodness, and certainly so charming a lady cannot fail to have a tender heart for the unhappy; but I am without a friend in England, except this worthy gentleman, and I do think he will advise me for the best. It seems to me that you are not quite estrang'd to one another: Mr. Mowbray is very honorable and good to poor me; I pray you let me hear what he will say.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Speak, Frederick!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I scarce know how to answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: If you believe me worthy of the trust, and sincere in wishing for it—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: How can I doubt of either? But my con∣nection with this lady is a delicate one.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I must suppose it is an honorable one.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P:
In the strictest sense. Gratitude not less than, under Providence, for my life, bind me to Sabina Rosny. Through the sad period of an
excruciating illness, her soothing pity was my only support—snatch'd by her care from death, or a condition worse than death, could I do less than dedicate what's left of life and senses to the gene∣rous preserver of them? I am now going to my father—I need not say how much my fate de∣pends upon that interview.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: No, no, no! I do once more pray and implore of you, Mr. Frederick, not to speak of me to your father: I have reasons for that, which it would be great pain and difficulty for me to expli∣cate to you; but, since my lady is so good to per∣mit me to come to her, I do pray you let me avail myself of her kind favor, and then, when I will make my confession to her, you shall find yourself very happy that you have not spoken to your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Go then, and may you find your happiness where mine was lost!—Oh, Lady Ruby, pardon a distracted mind—

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Be tranquil, my good friend, you shall have no cause to complain of me; and I am per∣suaded this lady, who has the beauty of an angel, has also the benevolence of one.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: My lady, I am your ladyship's most obe∣dient humble servant!—Pray, my lady, excuse this seeming want of manners; if we had had any item of your ladyship's doing us this great honor, things shou'd have been in another sort of fashion to have welcom'd such a visitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Sister and I had but just stept out!

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Yes, my lady, brother Billy and I had but just stept out to provide something dainty for our charming guest—and a lovely young lady she is, tho' I say it to her face, as any in the kingdom, your ladyship always excepted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P:
No apology to me, my good Mrs. Ca∣therine; your brother knows that my business
relates only to some small accounts of Sir Paul Ruby's, and those can be adjusted at any other time as well as the present.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: They are all ready, my lady; examin'd, vouch'd, and balanc'd, with your leave I will bring up the abstract, and pay in the amount.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Another time, if you please; 'till then I will trouble you to be my banker; every body knows your punctuality, my good friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Pretty correct, pretty correct, I flatter myself, fair lady: hav'nt lost my credit yet—hope I never shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: There is a loss however you must be prepar'd for; I am going to rob you of your ami∣able guest: you must pardon me if I take Made∣moiselle Rosny with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Every thing this house contains is so en∣tirely at your ladyship's command, that if you was to take away not only my amiable guest, but sister Kate into the bargain, I must submit and obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Law! brother! how you talk! as if such a person as me could be company for her ladyship—but Miss Rosny deserves better entertainment than we can give her; and to be sure, if your ladyship so wishes, much as we shall feel the loss of her sweet society, yet, with Mr. Frederick's consent, we shall resign her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: I am very thankful, indeed I am, good madam and good sir, for your politeness; and I am persuaded that the more I had known you, the more and more I shou'd have lov'd you; but adieu for the present! I will pay you my devoirs as soon as it is in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: The blessing of blessings light upon you, sweet innocent! they must be monsters who cou'd harm you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Come, my dear, are you ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P:
One word with you, Mr. Frederick.—Ah, my good friend, give me your hand: I shall see you soon, and you shall know all my sad his∣tory; then you will pity and excuse me:
meanwhile I do pray, if you regard my happiness or your own, say not one word to your father on the subject we were speaking of.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: So far I promise you, 'till the mystery is cleared up.—Lady Ruby, I commit to your protec∣tion a tender pledge, which, if I had not kept sa∣cred whilst under guardianship of my honor, I were a wretch too hideous for society. What she has to reveal to you I know not: if misfortunes, you will pity them; if mistakes, you will pardon them—wrong'd she may be, guilty she cannot be.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Oh! Frederick, Frederick! I have much to say to you—many things to explain, and some∣thing to impart that will surprise you—Be cautious in your language to your father. After you have conferr'd, let me see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Is it possible you can wish it? Is there an object so unwelcome, so proscrib'd as I am?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: If your heart suggests that question, why do you trust me with a charge so dear to you? And, if you were unwelcome, why did I solicit the trust? Ah! where is your wonted intuition?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I can make no reply; I'll strive to fortify my heart, and wait upon you—Shall I attend upon you to your coach?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: By no means; stay where you are.—Here is my beau.
SP.STAGE: [Exit, attended by Bustler, and followed by Sabina and Mrs. Catherine.

SP.SPEAKER: Frederick,
SP.P:
Where am I? What is this obscurity, that ga∣thers like a cloud ready to burst upon me? Sabina meditates to set me free—but why? I cannot pe∣netrate her motives: I have no trace of what I may have divulg'd in the wand'rings of my reason. Perhaps she has discover'd my first love in the per∣son of this lady, and means to make a generous sa∣crifice of her right in me—I'll not permit it: no! tho' my heart should burst with the recoil of that unconquerable affection, which the sight of my
enchantress has reviv'd, I never will submit to be a villain, and abandon my preserver.—David!

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Aye, sure enough I am he.—Where's Mademoiselle?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Gone with Lady Ruby.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Is she so? then I caught a glimpse of her for the first time.—Well! I say nothing, every man to his own fancy; but for my part, brother Frederick, if little England cou'd'nt furnish me with a mate to my liking, I wou'd be content to go single for the rest of my days.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: David, we won't talk upon that subject just now.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Very well, then you must keep clear of father, for he will talk of nothing else; yet I think you shou'd speak him quickly, for it's out of chance for you to lie hid in this tattling town much longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I waited only till Sabina was dispos'd of, and am going to him directly. Will you accom∣pany me?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: To be sure I will, if you wish it—But harkye, Frederick, I hope you don't take in ill part what I said to you, only because I thought it a pity an honest Englishman shou'd go out of his own country for a wife; whereas, do you see, if your heart is pledg'd, why there's an end of the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: There let the matter end then.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Enough said, leave it there; only if father comes down upon you with a spanking breeze, I wou'd not have him take you at a non-plus.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P:
A man, who knows his duty, cannot be surpriz'd: I am his son in all lawful service, but where my honor is engagd, friend David, I think you will agree with me that an honest heart ought not to be shaken either by menaces or soothings;—
so let us bold'y set forward, face our fortune, and defy its malice.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Come on, my brave fellow! to the last breath of my life I will stand by you; and if father cuts you off with a shilling and leaves me his estate, the shilling shall be mine, and the estate shall be your's.
SP.STAGE: SCENE changes to an apartment in Sir Miles's house.
(A Servant passes the stage—Mr. Wrangle follows.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Robin, Robin!—A word in your ear—

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: I humbly beg your pardon, Mr. Wrangle, I did not see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: No offence, my good friend, no of∣fence—How are you, honest Robin?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Thank you, Sir! What are your com∣mands, I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Where's your master? where's Sir Miles? I want a word or two with him in pri∣vate.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: I'll tell him as much.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Do so, do so! I'm determin'd it shall come out: she threatens to complain of me to her father; and as she always takes care to have the last word, it is but fair that I should have the first.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: I crave your pardon, Sir, but I hope you have no bad news about my young mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Why shou'd you suppose it, Robin?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Because I hear she had an accident at the opera door; no bad consequences from the fright I hope—Oh! here my master comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: So, Wrangle, what's the best news with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: I cannot say, Sir Miles, that I have any particular good news to impart to you; and yet, with your leave, I would fain solicit your attention for a few minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: What's the matter now? Why do you round me with a circumbendibus in this man∣ner, when I so often desire you to speak plainly, and to the point at once?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Well, Sir, then to the pointat once.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: To be sure, that's the way to be un∣derstood, son Wrangle; whereas to be verbose and circumstantial, is to be tedious; and when a man is tedious, you know, 'tis ten to one if his hearers are not tir'd with his preamble, before he lets them into the body of his bill.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: At the present moment I conceive that fault does not lie with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I don't say it does, I don't say it does; yet a fault it is, lie where it will, and every man has his faults, which it is the part of a friend to tell him of, it is the part of a father—You yourself are not without faults, son Wrangle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: I own it, Sir; I do not affect to dis∣guise them; but the faults I would recommend to your cognizance are secret faults, which you do not see, and which I cannot remedy without your help.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Come, come, Sir, my insight may go deeper than you are aware of; I have spied out some lurking peccadilloes in a certain person, which I shall not descant upon in your hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Peccadilloes, do you call 'em? they merit a much harder name, believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Well, well, well; if for obvious rea∣sons I don't give them hard names, let that be no proof with you I mean to overlook them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: I hope you will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P:
Be sure of that, son Wrangle; you will hardly doubt but I have my daughter's inte∣rest very thoroughly at heart, and, having been the author of your union, feel myself responsible
for the happiness or unhappiness that may result from it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Sir Miles, I honor you for the can∣dor of that very liberal confession: Our's was not a match of passion; prudence concerted our al∣liance, and on your wisdom I repos'd my hopes; but indeed, and indeed I am not what I seem; I am not that happy man you suppos'd me to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Why, I'm sorry for it, but don't de∣spair; confiding your situation to me, you take a prudent step, and you shall find me, my dear Wrangle, a zealous friend to serve you—Tempers may be corrected! there shall be no want of admo∣nition on my part, in your behalf; in the mean time let it be a secret between you and me; don't tell your wife a word of what is pass'd: I shall take the affair into my own hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Well, Sir, on that condition I will not let her know I have appeal'd to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Every husband ought to keep up his consequence and authority; whereas this wou'd only tend to lower you in her respect, as if you had not power of yourself to regulate your own concerns, without calling me in to assist you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: 'Tis very true, I see your motives, and am beholden to you for them. Under your fa∣therly correction, worthy Sir, I may now flatter myself we shall go on better than ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I hope you will—and now you see the good effects of plain speaking; let me advise you never to be circumlocutory any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Oh Sir, Sir, Sir! rare news! Master Frederick is arriv'd well and hearty; Heaven be prais'd for all things!—Humbly beg pardon for my boldness, but I cou'dn't contain myself for joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P:
How, how, how is all this?—Aye, there he is, sure enough, my own dear boy come home again.—Welcome, Freddy, welcome again
and again! And how are you, my brave fellow? glad to see old England once more?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I am happy to see you, Sir, in such health and spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Why, for health, thank Heaven! I am pretty well; for spirits, look you, I am all the better for the sight of you.—But hold, hold! here's a new relation of your's, Caleb Wrangle, Esquire, husband to our Lyddy, and such a hus∣band.—Bear up, Wrangle! I'm no blab.—[aside.]—(Aye, that's right, that's right! take him by the hand; give him joy!) though I say it to his face, I don't know such another. Davy knows what a sond couple they are; don't you, Davy?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Not I, father; that's only known to themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Out upon thee, surly boots! wilt never be civiliz'd?—Wrangle, I am staunch; I'll stand by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: We are so rarely favor'd with our brother David's company, that he cannot witness what he does not see: I flatter myself Mr. Fre∣derick will be more neighbourly; but I'll not in∣trude upon moments so precious—I'll run home to my belov'd, and gladden her fond heart with the joyful tidings.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: There he goes, the paragon of hus∣bands, bating a few infirmities of temper, which I shall soon correct.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: I'll lend you a hand heartily at that job, father, if you want a mate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, sirrah; if you were as free to find out your own failings, and as candid to confess them, as he is, you would be fitter for society than you are▪—I hope, son Fre∣derick, you at least like your new brother-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I hope my sister does, Sir,; that is most to the purpose: All I can say of him is that he seems a very civil, smooth-spoken gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P:
You are right, a little too oily-tongu'd; that is a fault to be sure, but I shall correct
that: I own I like a man that speaks his mind boldly.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Not when it does not fall in with your own, father.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Peace, puppy!—I'm now coming to the point with you Frederick.—I have sent for you home upon an affair of the last consequence to your happiness and my own: Your first love, Lady Ruby, is now a free woman, and one of the greatest fortunes in the kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Her fortune is no lure to me.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: You like a man that speaks his mind boldly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Get out of my sight!—Her fortune no lure! You was in love with her then for her poverty, was you not? You lik'd her best when you had a fair chance of starving with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Not so, Sir; but as you consider'd her good qualities but as dust in the scale 'till money was thrown into it, I consider money but as dust to dust.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Your humble servant, Sir!—You may march back to your old quarters; your head is turn'd, you have fill'd it with foreign vapor and outlandsh rhodomontade.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I hope I did not go out of my own coun∣try to be taught the duties of a man of honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I wish you wou'd learn the duties of a son, and not insult my ears with that puppily word honor: I can remark you have always the honor to think differently from me; if it was not for that same honor of running counter to my wishes, you wou'd run into this lady's arms; your honor was eager enough for it, when I stood your friend, and oppos'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Aye, father, you spoke your mind boldly then, and now it's Frederick's turn to speak his.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P:
Saucebox! jackanapes! impudent varlet! If you don't instantly vanish, by the horns
of Jupiter Ammon, I swear I will extinguish you.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Say no more, father! I'm off!—Good morning to you. Marry, I'd rather mess with you a week than a fortnight.—By the horns of Jupiter Ammon—that's a good one, by the Lord Harry!—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: With your permission, Sir, I will take my leave for the present—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Sir, you may take it for everlasting—I care not what becomes of a reprobate son.
Ah! poor Wrangle! he has a thousand faults, but what then? he has the grace to own them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Ruby.
SP.P: I PRY not into your secrets amiable Sabina; tell me nothing that will give you pain to re∣veal; but treat me as a friend, who needs no spur to serve you, nor any other testimonies of your innocence than you carry in your countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Ah! my dear good lady! you are very considerate of me, and have great pity for unhap∣py Sabina; but it is my duty to explain to you my follies as well as my misfortunes: You are too good in crediting me for my innocence, but I will not be a deceiver, tho' I have myself been sacri∣fic'd by deceit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: What do I hear? Has Frederick—

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Oh! no, no, no! He is perfection of a man, and if he did know my wrongs, I do believe he wou'd expose his life for my redress; therefore I will not let the name of my betrayer pass my lips, for fear that it shou'd reach his ears.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: How's this, Sabina? Have you been wrong'd, betray'd, and yet did you consent to Frederick's proposal?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Not for the universe wou'd I consent; for I do know his heart too well, and my own conscience still better. Ah! my dear lady, if you can pity me, a stranger, for my sufferings, what must you feel for his, when you shall know your∣self to have been the cause of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I!—I the cause of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Ah! yes indeed; it was your marriage broke his heart, his brain; he was a dying, a dis∣tracted man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: How cou'd my marriage so affect him? Had he not forsaken me, had he not renounc'd me, I wou'd have suffer'd death ere I wou'd have join'd my hand to any other man's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: I know not how that was, I only know how he did rave when his poor mind was gone, and his life almost at the last moment: I'm sure, if ever woman was ador'd by man, you are by Mr. Frede∣rick; for myself then, if I was free (which I am not) judge if I cou'd in honor marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Did he not freely offer it? Does he not still most strongly press it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: He presses it in honor, not in heart; and when he offer'd it he was beside himself with rage and disappointment for the loss of you: In fine, my Lady, I do wish I had a friend just now, who wou'd say to Mr. Frederick, that Sabina Rosny cannot, if she wou'd, accept his hand; and further, if she cou'd, for his sake she wou'd not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: And who so fit to say that, as Sabina Rosny herself?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Alas! Alas! how difficult for me, how dangerous for him! If I shou'd say how I was treated by a certain person of this country, (I did believe all Englishmen were honest) wou'd he not force me to confess the whole? And then—Oh terrible! Is it not better I shou'd bury my sad story in my heart, and suffer in secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: A villain shou'd be dragg'd to light, and punish'd by the world's contempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Let his own conscience be his punish∣ment! Tho' he has ruin'd me, basely betray'd me by a pretended marriage, and then cruelly aban∣don'd me; what can I say or do? Shall a poor alien like me contend with power like his?—Your laws will not redress me; my religion is not his religion: I know not who is that Italian monk that married us; I know not where to find him; or, if I cou'd, what then? My Lord wou'd little care for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P:
My Lord shall care; doubt not but there are means to make him care, and feel and
tremble for his character, which public fame shall blast thro' all the world, unless he does you right.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: But you don't know him; I did say too much when I said unawares "my Lord," but yet I have not nam'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I know his name, his nature too I know, and how susceptible he is of the world's fame, how quick of feeling.—Am I not right, Sabina? Is he not very, very—Sensitive?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Ah! (shrieks)—You are magicienné.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Come, come, you see you might as well have trusted me at once; I've fathom'd your deep secret. Be now convinc'd, Sabina, a man cannot do wrong in this country, and escape discovery; in the next place assure yourself Lord Sensitive is not that man, who can offend without atoning for it: Honor belongs to him still, tho' he can shift it off a-while, but nakedness will soon shame him into wearing it again—Hark! we have a visitor—per∣haps you'll wish to ponder on these things in private.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: I pray you let me retire—my heart is very full.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: If am too bold in approaching you without special permission, your servants are in the fault, who said they had orders to admit me without reserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: They told you truth; you may remem∣ber I said my doors were open to all persons of honor; and who fulfils that character more com∣pletely than Lord Sensitive?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: But might I not have interrupted a con∣versation more agreeable than Lord Sensitive's?—Frederick Mowbray is come home.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Well, if he is?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P:
Then there is one more votary (and no mean one, I confess) to offer incense at the shrine
of that divinity, whom all men worship, and all women envy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I cou'd give you a reason, my Lord, which I am sure you wou'd admit to be conclusive, against Mr. Mowbray's addressing me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: May I ask what shou'd prevent him from paying his addresses to your ladyship?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Simply this—because he has pledg'd them elsewhere, and is too much a man of honor to violate his engagements.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Oh!—if he is engaged elsewhere—that is if—if he is absolutely bound—that alters the ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: To be sure it does: I knew you wou'd allow the reason to be good; I knew you wou'd feel the force of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I do indeed—I feel the force of it very thoroughly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I'm satisfied you do, and I hope you will credit me when I declare to you, upon the word of truth, that if Frederick Mowbray was the one man whom I preferr'd before all men living, and I knew him guilty of having pledg'd his faith to another woman, whom he afterwards abandon'd, I wou'd as soon join hands with infamy, and be the outcast of society, as with such a traitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: That—that is very strong, Lady Ruby, and bespeaks your utter abhorrence of double-dealing; but you will permit me to observe that much wou'd depend upon who, and what the woman was.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I wou'd not hear of such a plea, and you, my Lord, wou'd be the last man living to allow of it; 'twou'd be a mere evasion, not a miti∣gation of his guilt—Every mean wretch can blast the reputation of the fond believing victim, whom his unmanly cunning has seduc'd, and his unprin∣cipled inconstancy deserted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: That is quite unanswerable, Lady Ruby; that brings it home to a man's conscience, I con∣fess: I have nothing to offer in defence of such a proceeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: No, no, there is no sophistry can pal∣liate seduction—What then wou'd you say, if, in aggravation of his wickedness, he had abus'd her credulity by a pretended marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Madam!—Madam!—Who told you this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Who told me? What is it you mean? I am supposing a case, and did you understand I was stating a fact? I hope there is no one (of my acquaintance at least) whose conscience can plead guilty to a charge like this; if there is, I am sure Frederick Mowbray is not the man.—So now your Lordship sees I have set you perfectly at your ease about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I cannot say Madam, I am just now perfectly at my ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Why how now, my good Lord! I think I have been tolerably explicit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I don't complain of that; I perfectly understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Well then, what ails you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Oh! I have many ails.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: What other phantom have you conjur'd up?—Come, come, you are very dull company; I shall not let you in another time, if you are such a melancholy gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I will ask to be admitted to you but once more, before I take my leave for ever. I most heartily beg your pardon for all the foolish things I have said or done since I had the honor of know∣ing you: I was betray'd into involuntary admira∣tion; it is not easy to reflect within the sphere of your attraction, but I have regain'd my senses, and shall be out of England before three days are at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Aye, so you say; but this is one of your freaks: however, I conjure you let me see you before you go—Promise me this—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Upon your honor?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Solemnly I promise—Then you shall know me better.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Ah! Billy, my fine fellow, how fares it with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: I don't know whether I shall speak to you; I am not sure I shall acknowledge you.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Heyday! What's in the wind now, my heart of oak? What have I done to offend you?

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: What have you done? Inquire of sister Kate; she'll let you know what you have done, and set her claws into your face at the same time for your doings. You have brought a naughty woman into our house.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: 'Tis false.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Don't say so! I have proof positive.—She a virtuous suffering innocent!—She to be married to your brother Mowbray! No such thing, friend David; she is married already, and your honorable brother has made free to steal a march with another man's wife.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, Billy, in one word—either prove what you say, prove it upon the spot, or fall to your prayers and take leave of life, for damn me if you don't tread upon your grave!

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Read then, and be convinc'd—Here is a trinket sister Kate found in her drawer after she had left us: 'tis the portrait of some gentleman; his name is not to it, but see what is inscribed at the back.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Give it me, give it me—I shou'd know this face.—Aha! my Lord, have I discover'd you?—Now for the writing at the back, "The husband of the forsaken Sabina!"—Damnation!
