Does the world contain such villainy? I'll make him swallow it, aye and digest it, ere I suffer my poor brother to be so abus'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Why, you astonish me; I never cou'd have thought—

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Mark me! Don't think at all, for this business belongs to me: Your only part is to be in∣violably secret, husht as death, till I have sifted it to the minutest grain: That done, I will report to you the particulars, and then, as I am sure my brother's honor will come out clear as the light, you must revoke every syllable you have utter'd in∣jurious to his reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Billy B.
SP.P: Aye, aye, revoke—one of us must re∣voke; sor I'll swear there is a foul trick some∣where.—So your humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Now which tack shall I be upon? Whether to begin first with Madam, or Monsieur; (for I am positive this leering traitor is Lord Sen∣sitive) or, first and foremost, to make sure of my poor Frederick, and snatch him from the snare, is a question that—I need not debate upon, for here he comes.—How now, Fred, whither bound?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: In your phrase I answer, on a dangerous coast; I believe I am rash enough to be going to Lady Ruby.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: I believe not.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Why do you say that?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Because I think your rashness will not attempt to make its passage thro' my body, and there is no other road.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I comprehend you, and I take your mo∣tive in good part: You see my weakness, you per∣ceive I am relapsing into my former passion for Lady Ruby, and you tremble for the honor I have pledg'd to Sabina Rosny.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: You are right; I tremble for your ho∣nor, I plant myself between you and ruin; and I conjure you, nay, I compel you turn back with me from that house, which will else be the tomb of your happiness, your fortune, and your fame.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: I cannot now; I will hereafter.—Answer me this, are you married to the Frenchwoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I am not.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Thank Heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Speak of her however more respectfully, if you mean we should be friends.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Friends, friends! Who dares to call my friendship into question, when I have pledg'd it to a brother?—I am no trifler, Frederick.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I will not treat you as such, but follow you as my guardian genius, sent to snatch me from disgrace; for, alas! I must confess to you I am lost if I behold that syren, who first took possession of my soul.—Come, let us fly! Whither shall we go? Carry me to my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: To your sister then!—Hav'nt you seen her yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Not I; Lady Ruby, Lady Ruby is the loadstone that draws away every particle of steel that shou'd fortify my heart, and leaves it weaker than a woman's tear.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: What's all that, brother? A kind of gabble I don't deal in, nor aim to understand: Let actions speak for me.—Come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Tell your mistress I wou'd speak with her before she goes out. Hold! I see she is coming—Leave me.
So, Madam, you are on the wing, I perceive: Have you any very pressing engagements on your hands?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Half a hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P:
And suppose I had a wish to engross a few minutes of your conversation, how many of
these very pressing engagements wou'd you dispense with at my request?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Ridiculous! What conversation can you want with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: A very serious one, be assur'd; there∣fore, with your leave, I will dismiss your equipage, and in place of half a hundred frivolous visits, re∣commend you a more profitable method of dis∣posing of your time with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Hold, Sir! are you mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: No, Madam, I am not mad; nor will I suffer you to act as if you were.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Do you mean to make your house my prison? Shall I not be allowed to visit my own father?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: By all means your father: I'll go with you to Sir Miles myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: You are a bold man, Mr. Wrangle, if you will venture to face that accusation which I shall prefer against you: I shou'd doubt if your hypocrisy will bear you out with my too credulous father any longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Try it, Mrs. Wrangle; I shall resort to no hypocrisy; truth will serve my purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Are you sure of that? Shan't you feel a little awkward in attempting so very new an ex∣periment? I rather think your interest lies in a quarter opposite to truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: I believe, Madam, you will find it pretty strong in a quarter you don't suspect: If you are wise, you will be silent; Sir Miles Mow∣bray knows you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: From your report, I defy him or any person else to know me, for your malice is too gross to escape detection, and your wit too dull to make even scandal entertaining.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Mr. Frederick and Mr. David Mowbray.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: There, there! My protectors are at hand.—Welcome, my dear Frederick! Welcome to England! Welcome to the rescue of your poor imprisoned sister, whose heart panted to be with you, but whose tyrant husband, lost to all human feelings, wou'd not suffer her to depart from his doors!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: What is all this? Can you explain it, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Oh, yes! he can explain any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: How greatly I am shock'd, I need not say.—I came to give you both a joyful greeting; I am saluted by one party with a flaming accusation, by the other with a sullen reserve. What am I to say?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: The less the better, between man and wife.—I hope, gentlemen, you do not combine to over-awe me in my own house.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Step out of it then with me: the open air is common property, and we will talk together man to man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: I shall do no such thing: It is enough for me that I am married to your sister; I am not bound to risk my life against her brothers.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: It will not be requir'd of you, Mr. Wran∣gle—My brother David is too quick; and I am sure, when I tell him it is my particular request, he will have the kindness to withdraw.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: With all my heart, for I never wish to be under the same roof with the man I despise.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Hush, hush! Impetuous boy!

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Harkye, Frederick, a word in your ear—Don't quarrel with him; he's below your anger. I am going to Lady Ruby; come to me there; I have thought better of it since I prevented you a while ago, and have a secret to communicate worth a King's ransom—Don't fail me. And, look! by Saint George and the Dragon, here comes my father, a joyful witness to the happiness of a match of his own making.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: What does the puppy prattle about?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Oh Sir, Sir! don't reprove him for his generous indignation against a cruel husband, who oppresses and insults your poor suffering daughter, 'till no longer able to endure her sorrows and his tyranny, she is compell'd to cast herself at your feet, and implore your pity and protection.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I'm thunderstruck! I'm petrified!—This is one fault more, Wrangle, than I thought you had.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Rise, sister, rise! You are too vehement in your remonstrance; I must believe it is not in this gentleman's nature to oppress or insult an un∣offending wife, which I hope you are; and I am heartily sorry you make our father a party in your little domestic squabbles, which might easily be adjusted without his privity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Give me your hand, Frederick, you speak like an angel. I am friends with you from this moment for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Thro' the favor of Mr. Mowbray's temperate interposition, for which I am greatly be∣holden to him, I flatter myself I may now have leave to speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: By all means Mr. Wrangle, by all means; no man speaks better when his own faults are the topic, and I do not forget the promise I have made you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: To that promise I now appeal. The cause of Mrs. Wrangle's complaint is simply this—She had ordered her coach to make half a hundred idle visits, and I, in the expectation of her brother's coming, wou'd fain have prevail'd with her to stay at home and receive him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Monstrous prevarication!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Hush, child, hush!—A small stretch upon the truth would have been a softer phrase.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Now, Sir Miles, if you recollect what I hinted to you about your daughter's temper—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: About my daughter's temper! What is it you mean?—I heard a pretty many broad hints of your own temper, but not one of my daughter's.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Of my temper, Sir? No; whatever faults there may be in my temper, I owe no ac∣count of them to you; because, if you had taken the smallest pains to know me before I married Miss Mowbray, you must have seen and confess'd I was the last person living to make her happy, or be happy with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I wish you had imparted that to me in good time—Your intelligence, Mr. Wrangle, is rather of the latest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: It is very true, Sir; and had you given me leave to chuse a husband for myself, Mr. Wrangle, be assured, is just the very last man in existence, on whom I shou'd have fix'd my choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Heyday! why then did you both agree in persuading me you were the happiest fondest couple in all England?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: You persuaded yourself: We were miserable enough methinks not to be mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: 'Tis very true: Mrs. Wrangle herself will do me the justice to say I never pretended to be happy with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: No, no, we had both a very sovereign dislike for each other: 'Tis the only point we ever agreed in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Your most obedient humble Servant! I am very much oblig'd to you both; and as you so lovingly agree in laying all your faults upon me, I leave you in a perfect state of harmony with each other—and I pray Heaven you may live long to enjoy it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Sister, sister, make it up, I conjure you; where there is blame on both sides, you shou'd ex∣change forgiveness.
SP.STAGE: (Mr. and Mrs. Wrangle, after a pause.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Mrs. Wrangle—Love!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Mr. Wrangle—My dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: I begin to think—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: What do you begin to think?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: That we have expos'd ourselves very sufficiently.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Quite enough in all conscience.—Why would you complain to my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Why wou'd you complain to your brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: We were both to blame: Complaints are very foolish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Then away with them at once, say I.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: For ever! Let us forbear to gratify our friends, by never publishing our disagree∣ments.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: And cure the world of its contempt, by never calling upon it for its pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Agreed! Here's my hand upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: And here's my heart; to which I press you with the warm affection of a husband, that will never cool.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: And I return it with the love and duty of a wife; who will never create a murmur, nor utter one again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Why this is happiness without hypo∣crisy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Perfect felicity unfeigned.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Oh! joyous husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Oh! transported wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Ruby.
SP.P: OUT upon you, false loon! What can you say for yourself, for not having been near me these three long days?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Lord love you, my dear Lady, I have been brushing up and down this great town about my ship affairs, here and there, and every where—And now you know brother Frederick is come home.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Oh! you sea-creature, was you half as much of a lover as you are of a hero, you wou'd understand that no excuse will serve for neglecting a fond woman.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Always a dab for poor David—but when I am at sea again, and sailing in the Venus, I shall never cast a look upon the figure at the head, with∣out thinking of your ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: That's very fine, David—but come, be sincere, is'nt it the bon-mot of the ship? Can you lay your hand on your heart, and declare you ne∣ver said that to any body before.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Never, never; tho' I don't deny but others have, for I heard Joe Jackson, our gunner, say it to his wife as she went over the side at part∣ing.—And now to my business: I have a small matter of property belonging to Mademoiselle Rosny, which I wou'd fain deliver into her own hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: From your brother, we'll suppose—

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: I rather suppose not—Here it is; not very like Frederick—is it, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Lord Sensitive to the very life. Where did you pick up this?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Billy Bustler delivered it to me, open as you see; they found it in her toilette, after she had left the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Have you shewn it to your brother?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: I hardly thought that necessary, as the inscription on the back shews the lady to be al∣ready provided with a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I see it.—Alas! poor Sabina! this confirms her own sad story, and his lordship's guilt.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Does it not do something more than that, if the lady has been carrying on designs upon my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: There you do her wrong.—Who waits?—(Enter Servant.)—Tell Mademoiselle Ros∣ny I desire to speak with her.—(Exit Servant.)—She has no designs upon your brother, but in the most decided manner has declined his honorable offers. If she has withheld the secret from him hitherto, it is simply because she wou'd not involve him with Lord Sensitive.—Oh! here she comes!—
My dear, this young officer is your friend Mr. Mowbray's brother—I don't know if you have met before.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: I do not remember to have had that honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: He has something in charge to return to you, from the good people in whose house he procur'd you a reception.—Do you recollect hav∣ing left any small article of your property behind you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: A picture—I have been searching for it every where.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: I am happy to restore it to you, and wish I cou'd at the same time restore the original to a sense of his honor, for I feel it as a disgrace to myself to own him for my countryman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: It is so your brother wou'd have said, if he had seen it; which I hope he has not.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P:
No, no, madam; man to man is a fair match; there is no need of two masters to teach
one worthless individual his duty.—My sword is at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Heaven forbid I shou'd employ your sword, when your country has such need of it! In defending that you defend me, and thousands like me, who refuge in its generous protection.
SP.STAGE: (A Servant enters, and whispers Mr. DAVID.)

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Very well! I'll come to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: What does he tell you?

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: My brother is below.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: My dear Sabina, do your spirits serve you for an interview with Mr. Mowbray?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Aid me, my good lady, and I will do my possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Say to Mr. Mowbray, we request the favor of his company. (Exit Servant.)—Now, my brave lad, recollect we are not to aggravate your brother's mind against Lord Sensitive, for whom I take upon myself to answer; and you, Sabina, whose gentle bosom has long labor'd with a painful secret, be assur'd one short and final ef∣fort will conclude your sufferings, and restore you to your peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Mr. Mowbray we rejoice to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I have obey'd your ladyship's commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: You wou'd greatly have disappointed our wishes, if you had not. You see I have your amiable fellow-traveller in safe keeping; how I have fulfill'd my trust, and whether I deserve a fur∣ther continuation of it, you have a right to know, and she will take occasion of informing you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I cannot doubt your kindness, nor her proper sense of it.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Lord! brother! how you stand!—Oh! that I might but speak!

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P:
Sabina, I am prepared to expect some discovery from you, that I am interested to be
inform'd of: I rely upon your candor for the fullest satisfaction, but if you would consult my feelings, you will ask permission of Lady Ruby that we may retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: As it shall be your will, so am I—But if my lady, who knows my sad history, and how I am embarras to relate it, wou'd have pity for my con∣fusion—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Oh! Sabina, Sabina! you know not what you ask, nor see the ruin you invite upon yourself and me.—If you wou'd wish to preserve my senses, patiently to hear and honorably to decide, take me from hence without a moment's loss.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Come then with me; your happiness, my best of friends, is as my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Stop, if you please—this room is your's—David and I have something to discuss elsewhere.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: I wish you'd let me say it here—A little plain sailing would bring us all to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Are you offended with me, loveliest of women?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Not much, not quite past reconciliati∣on,—a little, it may be, a very little angry—but if you are dispos'd to make peace, here is my hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Oh! Heavens! my soul sinks in it.—Where, where are you Sabina?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: You are alarm'd for me, my dear dear friend, without a cause. It is my wish, my prayer, my supplication to Heaven for you, that you may be blest and happy all your long life with that charming lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Sabina, what have you a mind to make of me? a villain, a betrayer of my word and faith! or a distracted husband without heart or head?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P:
Husband! that cannot be. I tell you now in verity, as I did tell you before, you can∣not be my husband, because—because—Ah me!
ah me! How shall I speak it? I am much ashamed—

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Speak, I beseech you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Because—I am already married.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Married! it cannot be!—Married!—Beware, Sabina; solemnly I adjure you to reflect that my unalterable purpose cannot be dispens'd with. If, because you see me combating a passion that was once my master, you suppose me con∣quer'd, you mistake: my faith, my honor, my confirm'd experience of your virtues never can be shaken, be the trial ever so severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: I pray you pardon my poor mode of speaking, but I do feel your goodness at my heart—indeed, indeed I do; and be not angry with me, my good friend, for that I did not tell you this be∣fore, but it is true no less—I am a wife—I will not say a happy one, for it was not for me to find a heart like your's; but I will hope the best, for I have not merited to be forsaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Is there a monster living that wou'd for∣sake you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Oh! yes, for I am poor—My family, my fortune perish'd—yet I should not expect a noble Englishman would make my poverty my crime, when there was nothing else that he could urge against me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Sabina, I must now believe that you are serious; my part therefore must change with your condition: but, tho' some obligations are dissolv'd, others are left in force, which honor cannot acquit me of—therefore, before I ask the name of your betrayer, be he who may, I solemn∣ly devote myself to your redress.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Ah! that is why I tremble to disclose his name.—Oh! my dear friend, I pray you to excuse me this one day. My Lady Ruby flatters me with hopes all shall be well.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I must insist upon his name.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: No, no, you will not make me more unhappy than I am; you will not sure refuse my intercession, if I do pray you on my knees.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Hold, hold sweet supplicant, be not so humble! I will not wound your tender sensibility for all the earth: Compose yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Oh! when you are so good to me, how can I stop my tears?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: What can I say? what shall I do to com∣fort you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: I wish, I wish, my lady was but here.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Behold! she comes upon your wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: My dear, what ails you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Oh, he is so generous and so kind to poor Sabina, that my heart is fit to break: I do think he is the best man living, and I do know he loves you, my sweet lady—Heaven! how he does love you!—Will you, then, be very angry with me, if I shall be so bold to say, you are the only lady upon earth that does deserve him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Oh! you seducing creature, that is not his opinion; for there is only this distinction be∣tween your fate and mine, that Frederick ran from me before marriage, Lord Sensitive from you after it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Lord Sensitive! I'm thunderstruck,

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Ah! what have you said?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Was it a secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: So help me Heaven, I cannot name the man, whose honor I wou'd so implicitly have vouch'd for as Lord Sensitive.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: And he'll redeem his honor, be assur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Yes, or his life must answer it.—I know him well, brave, generous, quick to feel and to resent each breath that glances at his fame—Either there is some error in his brain, or else some vil∣lainous traducer has impos'd on his credulity—I'll probe him to the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Ah, Frederick! there are certain cases of the heart, which women are suppos'd to treat better than men—Leave this to me; if he does not receive his cure from under my hands, I'll then consent to turn him over as a desperate case to you.
That must be Lord Sensitive.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Ah misericorde! what will now come of me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Away, away! take your fair protegée off the field, and leave, it clear for me.—On your allegiance, Frederick, stir not from your post till I relieve you.
Now, conscience, take our part! 'tis your own cause, support it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Lady Ruby, I have remember'd my promise; and as I know your late impressive words were pointed at my heart, I beg leave to assure you they have reach'd it. When I say I am your con∣vert, need I add that I am prepared to make atone∣ment to Sabina Rosny?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: I congratulate your lordship on that re∣solution, and am persuaded you can only find your happiness where you have left your honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: I'll not attempt to varnish my misdeeds, I acknowledge that Sabina Rosny has every requi∣site of merit, birth, and beauty, to engage and fix my heart.—When I left her, on a sudden call to England, I was not guilty of a purpose o desert her; my promise of a speedy return was sincerely given—but in the interim—what shall I say? Your candor must supply the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: We'll talk not of the past: Sabina's candor, and your lordship's better thoughts, as soon as you shall meet, will bury all offences in obli∣vion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: You predict flatteringly, but I have many anxious hours to pass before that meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: 'Tis a long distance between this and Padua; but if your resolution is made up—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Unalterably—I shall set out within this hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Wait a few moments, then; and tho' I cannot promise you a wind, as witches did of old, I'll do my best to give you a quick passage.—Sit down; your sylph shall be at your elbow before you can well draw a sigh.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: What can she mean? what project has her active fancy sprung, to back this bold profes∣sion?—Hark! I hear her.—Well, fair sylph, I keep my post, and wait your promis'd favor.—Hah! what now?—Sabina! Heaven uphold me! from what cloud have you dropt down on earth?

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: My lord! my husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Come to my arms! Oh unexpected joy! Now we will part no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Indeed! will you not forsake your poor Sabina any more?—Ah! what sad moments I have pass'd, counting the hours for your return, day after day, but all in vain—No lord, no letter, no hope left at last, no country to receive me, no parents, brothers, friends to fly to: miserable me! I did believe I was renounc'd of Providence, and destin'd to despair.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: Oh my much-injur'd, my acknowledg'd wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: That has sweet sound with it: my heart is comforted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: My life shall be devoted to atonement.—Trust me, my sweet Sabina, 'tis not my nature to be base or cruel: once restor'd to your forgiveness, (and methinks your eyes promise me that) I will offend no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P:
I know not how to call it an offence; for what am I? My fortune nothing, my nobility a shadow—a heart to honor you is all that I can boast. How, then, can I be angry, if, when re∣turn'd to your own happy country, where so many fairer ladies court your attention, you forgot poor,
humble, lost Sabina?—But of this no more—I have a friend, an honorable, noble friend, to whom I owe this happy meeting; I must take you to him—give me your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: My heart and hand.—Thus led by vir∣tue, and restored to reason, I am a man again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Well, Sir, 'tis your own concern; if you are contented with each other, it's a proof you are soon pleas'd. Quarrel when you like, and make it up how you can, you have my leave. I find by late experience that the man who thinks for more heads than he carries on his own shoulders, lays out care for himself, and reaps no thanks for his kindness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P: Believe me, my good Sir Miles—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Pardon me, my good Sir Caleb; that is a weakness I am cur'd of.—I was the dupe of credulity, when I believ'd you wou'd make my daughter happv, and when I took your word for your being so: I was the veriest dolt in creation, when I thought I could either qualify your fail∣ings, or compose your squabbles.—I pray you, Sir, be husband and wife in your own way, and never let me be middle man between you, henceforth and for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Oh! my dear, dear father! this is at length a joyful meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I am glad to hear it—what am I to be joyful for?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: For the total and compleat extinction of all possible dissensions between my beloved and myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: If he is your beloved, keep that a secret to yourself; at least don't insist on my believing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Nay, surely you'll believe me, and rejoice when I tell you that my ever-dear Mr. Wrangle—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Child, child, your fondlings make me sick, and your feuds make me sad; therefore let me have no more of either, I beseech you. (Frederick and David enter.) Welcome, welcome! Frederick, give me your hand; I have to ask your pardon for my folly, in supposing I had a right over your affections, first, by diverting them from the woman of your heart, and secondly by directing them towards her; and all my wonder is, you had the patience to listen to my nonsensical authority in either instance.—I have also an apology to make to that amiable lady for a most impertinent visit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: That amiable lady thinks the apology ra∣ther due for her reception of you, than for your visit to her; and before many minutes are gone by, I expect she will be here to tell you so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I can't believe it, Freddy: I won't believe it; 'tis a happiness above my hopes.—How now, Robert, how now?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Sir! your honor! she's a-coming, she's a-coming up the stairs—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Who's a-coming?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert
SP.P: Sir, the lady—the lady—I shall forget my own name—my young master knows who I mean.
SP.STAGE: [Frederick goes out to re∣ceive Lady Ruby.
(Lady Ruby, Lord Sensitive, and Sabina enter.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P:
My lady Ruby, this is indeed an ho∣nor and a happiness—and a—My Lord, I am
your most obedient; may I request to be made known to this fair stranger?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: This fair stranger, Sir Miles, whom I have the honor to call wife, is ambitious to pay her compliments to the father of her best friend, and my greatest benefactor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: Yes, truly, Sir, I am very happy to make my humble obeisance to you, for the sake of your honorable son, my very good friend, Mr. Frederick Mowbray; for whose favors I have not the words to speak my gratitude, tho' I have a heart, that will never cease to feel them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord S.
SP.P: If such be your gratitude, lovely Sabi∣na, what shou'd mine be to those friends of honor, who have restor'd you to my heart, and bless'd me with a prospect of that state of happiness, which I truly hope the married part of this company will continue to enjoy, and the unmarried make haste to obtain.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: Brother Wrangle, there's one wish for you and my sister, part it between you.—And brother Frederick, was I as you, I wou'd drop down on both my knees to my sweet Lady Ruby, and beg to go halves in the other wish with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sabina.
SP.P: And if my prayers cou'd profit, for his sake I wou'd kneel and pray, till some kind saint, that favors virtuous love, shou'd hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Oh! more than ever dear, long-lost, lamented, and despair'd of even to distracti∣on; has your once-tender heart, wean'd by time, or alienated by suspicion, forgot its former feelings?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Rise, Frederick, explanations of this nature shou'd be private; yet I will freely own, in presence of this company, 'twas the abrupt and se∣cret manner of your leaving me, which I could not reconcile to that generous sensibility I gave you credit for.—Did you write me one letter from abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: Several, many.—Did you answer one?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: As truth shall judge me, not a line of your's ever reach'd my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: I wish to my soul they had pass'd through mine; I wou'd have stak'd my life for the delive∣ry of them.—Father, I shou'd like to know if any body here present cou'd give an account of those same unlucky letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Say no more, say no more—My con∣science flies in my face: but a man can do no more than own it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.P: I have done—This only let me assert, in vindication of the truth, that I ceas'd not from the tenderest expostulations on your silence, im∣ploring you to keep me in your thoughts, and pro∣mising eternal constancy on my part, till I heard you was married—then I confess I was not hypo∣crite enough to send you my congratulations—my exhausted spirits sunk under the shock of that in∣telligence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady R.
SP.P: Here let us pause.—You have a zealous advocate, from whom I have heard the rest.—I have now only to apologize to Sir Miles Mowbray for my reception of his visit, which if he is not discourag'd to repeat, I can only assure him that the same proposal will not be treated with the same indifference.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: I am infinitely happy to hear you say so; but really, Madam, I am so confounded and asham'd of my past mistakes in cases of the heart, that I dare not venture upon more than putting up a prayer in secret for your happiness, and my son's. Hitherto I have been an officious, and I fear an unfortunate father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. W.
SP.P: Suffer me for a moment to interrnpt your self-reproaches, so far at least as they apply to me.—I now declare from my soul, that if a second choice was in my power, I would volun∣tarily fix it where you first directed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. W.
SP.P:
And I protest, with equal and unfeign'd sincerity, that, brought to recollection by this scene, and resolute to emulate the examples I
behold, my life shall be devoted to the blessing you bestowed upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Excellently resolv'd on both sides! I only hope you will not want me to put you in mind of it.

SP.SPEAKER: David.
SP.P: We all join in that hope.—Peace at home, for your sakes, ye happy husbands—war abroad for mine, and yours, my gallant com∣rades!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Miles.
SP.P: Corrected by experience, I will now venture to pronounce, that First Love is a faithful guide; and the parent, who attempts to turn that stream from its course, makes himselfe responsible for all the miseries and miscarriages, that may re∣sult from his diversion of it.

LG.L: TO you, fair Ladies, and, kind Sirs, to you,
Circle so brilliant, and to me so new,
I make my humble reverence, and I feel
More than in simple language can reveal;
In verity I thank you, and am sure,
Lodg'd in your bosoms I may sleep secure:
Blels your brave hearts, happy may you remain,
Tho' my poor country bleeds in ev'ry vein!
Ah woe the time! and, therefore, 'tis I see
So many pitying eyes are turn'd on me;
So kind they look, as if they wou'd impart
Some of their own brave spirit to my heart:
And where's the wonder, as the case appears,
If those who rule the waves shou'd calm our fears?
Oh! generous nation, pardon if I say
What my poor thoughts suggest in my poor way;
But I do think that Heav'n ordain'd a nest
On your white cliffs where halcyon peace may rest,
Sever'd one spot of consecrated ground,
And bade old Neptune roll his waves around:
Then put his trident in Britannia's hand,
And gave the watery world to her command;—
And she shall hold it for all time to come,
Tho' hair-brain'd prophets may denounce her doom;
For sure I am, the ruler of the wind
Will never harm the friends of human-kind.
But it is not for humble me to speak
Of things so great, with faculties so weak;
Enough that when I came, forsaken, poor,
A wand'ring emigrant, and sought your door,
Your generous favor gave me a retreat
Where the Muse haunts, and where the Graces meet,
Where beauty and benevolence unite
To cheer the soul and animate the sight,
Where from the fondé of the supporting pit,
Row above row the British worthies sit,
Presenting to the view a splendid ring,
Firm to their Country, loyal to their King;
And proving, by the grace with which they're pleas'd,
That the best Critics soonest are appeas'd.
